Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Rapid detection of phages in microbial fermentation processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to reduce cost and loss of productivity due to bacteriophage (phage) contamination in fermentation of dairy and other products. Bacteriophage contamination is the leading cause of failure in fermentation processes used in the food and pharmaceutical industries. The risk of phage contamination in food fermentation processes, particularly in the dairy industry, is significantly enhanced due to a large diversity of suppliers of both the raw ingredient (milk) and the necessary microbial cultures. The current and emerging analytical technologies cannot rapidly detect phages in food materials such as milk. Thus, the combination of the risk of contamination, and the lack of rapid detection methods, results in a significant economic loss for the dairy industry. Early detection of phage contamination will permit early intervention in the fermentation process, which will lead to significant cost savings. In addition, the test could be extended to other food areas, pharmaceutical production, and biochemical production.

The SBIR project addresses the need for rapid detection of phage contamination in a fermentation process through a novel photonic platform. The platform combines nanophotonics, microfluidics, and electrophoresis, and is based on discoveries made at University of California - Davis. The system is focused on the manipulation of charged phages with electrophoresis, and their accelerated amplification in bacteria. In addition, the system uses electrophoretic capture of phages into a nanophotonic crystal to achieve highly sensitive detection of the target phages. The salient features of the platform are: a) High-throughput, fast trapping of phages; b) excellent sensitivity and large dynamic range for quantification of phage concentration; and c) scalable design that can be produced at low cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A rapid, one-step assay that identifies the phage infection in dairy samples was demonstrated and validated by the cheese industry. Our assay has the rapidity of pH testing with the sensitivity of plating/plaque assay. Plaque assay is the gold standard for phage detection. This assay provides the number of phages in a given sample volume. However, the risk to the culture is dependent on the phage count and the virulence (phage burst and doubling time). PhageSensTMmonitors the phage activity in real-time, providing the combined effect of initial phage count and their virulence. Hence, the risk to the culture and the robustness of the culture can be analyzed for the first time. The assay can be used on starter cultures, milk, whey to test the phage infection within the facility. 

For the cheese maker our test gives a real-time phage monitoring system. This allows them to monitor and pull out cultures that show escalating phage infection. This not only prevents losses for the cheese maker, but also is beneficial for the culture supplier. Monitoring of phage infections on different cultures and the rotation of cultures to thwart phage build up at the facility allows the culture to be used for longer time without a crippling attack on the production.
